references.B05LAN01USGP: Lannoo, M. 2005. M. Lannoo (Ed.), Amphibian Declines. The Conservation Status of United States Species, University of California Press, Berkeley, CA (2005), p. 1094
references.B98CON02SEGP: Conant, R. and J.T. Collins. 1998. A field guide to the reptiles and amphibians: eastern and central North America. Houghton Mifflin, Boston. 616 p.
references.B89DUN01NAUS: Dundee, H. A., and D. A. Rossman. 1989. The amphibians and reptiles of Louisiana. Louisiana State Univ. Press, Baton Rouge.
references.B88ASH01NAUS: Ashton, R. E., Jr., and P. S. Ashton. 1988. Handbook of reptiles and amphibians of Florida. Part Three. The amphibians. Windward Publ. Co., Miami.
references.W15NAT01USGP: NatureServe. 2015. NatureServe Explorer: An online encyclopedia of life [web application]. Version 7.1. NatureServe, Arlington, Virginia. Available http://www.natureserve.org/explorer.
references.A40CAR01NAUS: Carr, A. F., Jr. 1940. A contribution to the herpetology of Florida. Univ. Florida Biol. Sci. Ser. 3:1.118.
references.W04HAM13USGP: Hammerson, G. 2004. Hyla avivoca. The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2014.3. <www.iucnredlist.org>. Downloaded on 10 May 2015.
references.B79BEH01NAUS: Behler, J. L., and F. W. King. 1979. The Audubon Society field guide to North American reptiles and  amphibians. Alfred A. Knopf, New York. 719 pp.
references.B95WIL01NCGP: Wilson, L. A. 1995. The Land Manager's Guide to the amphibians and reptiles of the South. Chapel Hill, NC: The Nature Conservancy.

habitat_description:
Found strictly in permanent wooded swamps that include cypress, birch, buttonbush, tupelo, and vine tangles (Behler and King 1979; Conant and Collins 1998). This species of frog is currently listed as threatened in Illinois due to drainage conditions of hardwood swamps (Redmer and Kruse 1998 in Lannoo 2005). Preferred breeding habitat includes hardwood swamps and forested floodplains. Strong association with cypress (Taxodium distichum) and Tupelo gum (Nyssa aquatic) trees (Lannoo 2005). When not breeding, adults can be found in low vegetation or on the ground nearby swamps (Redmer et al.1999 in Lannoo 2005).

The range of this species comprises extreme southwestern South Carolina, southwest across Georgia, Florida panhandle, southern Alabama, Mississippi, western Kentucky, Tennessee, and extreme southern Illinois; Isolated populations occur west of the Mississippi in central and northwestern Louisiana, the Red River Drainage of extreme southeast Oklahoma and Arkansas (Lannoo 2005). Extreme south Illinois to Louisiana and east of the Florida panhandle. Isolated populations in central Georgia, South Carolina, Alabama, Louisiana, Oklahoma, and Arkansas (Conant and Collins 1991).
